information:
According to public statements, François Villeroy de Galhau, a member of the European Central Bank (ECB) council, indicated there is room for gradual interest rate reductions as inflation approaches the central bank's 2% target. The ECB has implemented seven interest rate cuts since mid-2024, lowering the benchmark deposit rate to 2.25% as of its April 2025 meeting. ECB President Christine Lagarde has noted that future policy decisions will be data-dependent, citing 'unprecedented uncertainty'. A report from Qatar National Bank (QNB) stated that the ECB is expected to continue its interest rate cutting cycle in 2025, driven by a weak economic outlook for the Euro Area and stabilized inflation.

Official data from Eurostat showed the euro area annual inflation rate was 2.2% in March 2025, down from 2.3% in February. The primary contributors to the March inflation rate were services (+1.56 percentage points), followed by food, alcohol & tobacco (+0.57 pp), and non-energy industrial goods (+0.16 pp). Energy prices had a negative contribution (-0.10 pp). According to news reports citing polls from Bloomberg and Reuters, the consensus among economists for the April 2025 inflation figure is 2.1%. A quarterly Survey of Professional Forecasters by the ECB indicated that inflation for 2025 is expected to be 2.2%, with a forecast of 2.0% for 2026.

Recent economic indicators point to a weak economic outlook for the Eurozone. Real GDP growth forecasts for 2025 have been subject to downward revisions. For ten consecutive months, the composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI), which tracks business activity, has remained below or near the 50-point threshold separating contraction from expansion. The ECB's Wage Tracker Index indicates a rapid deceleration in wage increases from the peak observed in late 2024. This trend is expected to reduce price pressures in the labor-intensive services sector. Other disinflationary drivers include easing food inflation and a negative year-on-year contribution from energy prices.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: Approximately 3-5 days. Eurostat typically releases monthly inflation data in the first week of the following month, so April 2025 data should be published in early May 2025.
forecast.status_quo_outcome: Inflation continues its downward trajectory from March's 2.2% to the consensus forecast of 2.1% for April, resulting in a 'No' outcome (not above 2.2%).
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: April inflation comes in at or below 2.2%, consistent with the economist consensus of 2.1%. The disinflationary forces already in motion continue: energy prices remain a drag, food inflation continues easing, wage growth deceleration reduces services price pressures, and the weak economic environment (10 months of PMI near/below 50) keeps demand-side inflation subdued.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: April inflation unexpectedly holds steady at 2.3% or higher, or remains at March's exact 2.2% level but gets revised upward. This could occur if services inflation proves stickier than expected, food prices rebound, or there's an unexpected temporary shock. Month-to-month volatility in components like energy or seasonal adjustments could also push the figure above 2.2%.
forecast.rationale: The evidence strongly suggests inflation will not exceed 2.2% in April. The consensus forecast from Bloomberg and Reuters polls is 2.1%, below the threshold. The recent trend shows consistent deceleration: February 2.3% to March 2.2%, suggesting momentum toward the ECB's 2% target. Multiple structural disinflationary forces are active: energy prices contributing negatively (-0.10pp in March), food inflation easing, and the ECB's Wage Tracker showing rapid deceleration from late 2024 peaks, which should reduce price pressures in the labor-intensive services sector. The weak economic backdrop (PMI below/near 50 for ten consecutive months, downward GDP revisions) provides little demand-side support for sustained inflation above 2.2%. The ECB's aggressive rate-cutting cycle (seven cuts, bringing rates to 2.25%) reflects their confidence that inflation is under control. However, I'm not assigning an extremely low probability because: (1) March inflation was exactly at 2.2%, showing some stickiness; (2) services contributed significantly (+1.56pp) and can be volatile; (3) month-to-month statistical noise exists; and (4) preliminary estimates can have surprises. For me to revise higher, I'd need evidence of unexpected price pressures emerging, upward revisions to March data, or shifts in commodity/energy markets. For a lower forecast, I'd need to see preliminary regional data showing broad-based cooling or forward indicators pointing to faster disinflation.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will the Euro Area Inflation Rate be above 2.2% for April 2025?

Question background:
Euro News: [Euro falls as eurozone inflation sees downward revisions in February](https://www.euronews.com/business/2025/03/19/euro-falls-as-eurozone-inflation-sees-downward-revisions-in-february)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if the Eurozone inflation rate for April 2025 is above 2.2% on an annualized basis according to [Trading Economics](https://tradingeconomics.com/euro-area/inflation-cpi).




Your research assistant's report says:
According to public statements, François Villeroy de Galhau, a member of the European Central Bank (ECB) council, indicated there is room for gradual interest rate reductions as inflation approaches the central bank's 2% target. The ECB has implemented seven interest rate cuts since mid-2024, lowering the benchmark deposit rate to 2.25% as of its April 2025 meeting. ECB President Christine Lagarde has noted that future policy decisions will be data-dependent, citing 'unprecedented uncertainty'. A report from Qatar National Bank (QNB) stated that the ECB is expected to continue its interest rate cutting cycle in 2025, driven by a weak economic outlook for the Euro Area and stabilized inflation.

Official data from Eurostat showed the euro area annual inflation rate was 2.2% in March 2025, down from 2.3% in February. The primary contributors to the March inflation rate were services (+1.56 percentage points), followed by food, alcohol & tobacco (+0.57 pp), and non-energy industrial goods (+0.16 pp). Energy prices had a negative contribution (-0.10 pp). According to news reports citing polls from Bloomberg and Reuters, the consensus among economists for the April 2025 inflation figure is 2.1%. A quarterly Survey of Professional Forecasters by the ECB indicated that inflation for 2025 is expected to be 2.2%, with a forecast of 2.0% for 2026.

Recent economic indicators point to a weak economic outlook for the Eurozone. Real GDP growth forecasts for 2025 have been subject to downward revisions. For ten consecutive months, the composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI), which tracks business activity, has remained below or near the 50-point threshold separating contraction from expansion. The ECB's Wage Tracker Index indicates a rapid deceleration in wage increases from the peak observed in late 2024. This trend is expected to reduce price pressures in the labor-intensive services sector. Other disinflationary drivers include easing food inflation and a negative year-on-year contribution from energy prices.

Today is 2025-04-28.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
